diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when someone loses more fluids than they take in, potentially causing abnormal electrolytes, dysgeusia, and irritability.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones, leading to symptoms such as constipation and irritability.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Deficiencies in vitamins, such as vitamin B12 or vitamin D, can lead to irritability, abnormal electrolytes, and other nonspecific symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA)
diagnoses.description: A serious diabetes complication where the body produces excess blood acids (ketones), possibly causing dysgeusia and abnormal electrolytes.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by dry eyes and mouth, which could be interpreted as irritated eyes, along with potential dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.description: A disorder affecting the large intestine, causing symptoms like constipation, which may also influence irritability due to discomfort.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition marked by a deficiency of red blood cells or of hemoglobin in the blood, leading to symptoms like irritability and possibly abnormal electrolyte balance.

diagnoses.name: Renal Failure
diagnoses.description: A condition where the kidneys lose the ability to filter waste and balance electrolytes, leading to symptoms such as abnormal electrolytes and dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition, potentially causing irritability and other nonspecific symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mood disorder that causes a persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest, which can manifest physically as irritability, changes in eating habits leading to constipation, and other symptoms.

diagnoses: Diabetes Mellitus – considering the glycemic lability and poor healing, this could be a sign of uncontrolled diabetes affecting wound repair and possibly peripheral neuropathies.
Hyperthyroidism – goiter or Grave's disease can cause increased immunoglobulin levels (particularly thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin). Symptoms may include hyperactivity.
Multiple Sclerosis – an autoimmune disease that could explain increased immunoglobulins. Symptoms can be very diverse and may include muscle spasms.
Hemifacial Spasm – primarily affects one half of the face, including the eye. While not directly related to the other symptoms, it could co-occur with systemic issues.

Benign Essential Blepharospasm – a focal dystonia, primary symptom being the blepharospasm. The connection with the other symptoms may be more coincidental or indicative of an underlying systemic issue.

Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (CIDP) – could explain increased immunoglobulins and poor healing if nerves are severely impacted. Might also affect muscle control leading to spasms.

Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) – an autoimmune disease that might present with increased immunoglobulins and can affect nearly any part of the body, including nervous and endocrine systems, potentially contributing to hyperactivity and poor healing.

Sjögren's Syndrome – another autoimmune disorder predominantly affecting moisture-producing glands but can have systemic manifestations. Could potentially explain the blepharospasm if the eyes are dry and increased immunoglobulins.

Myasthenia Gravis – a chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease characterized by varying degrees of weakness of the skeletal (voluntary) muscles of the body. Can have increased immunoglobulins and might explain hyperactivity as a compensatory mechanism.

Neurofibromatosis – particularly NF2 could be associated with muscle spasms or contractions. While the other symptoms aren't classic, there could be an overlap or an indirect relationship through the disease's complications.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Autoimmune thyroiditis (such as Graves' disease for hyperthyroidism)
Thyroid Lymphadenitis (such as in Hashimoto's thyroiditis)

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: HIV/AIDS can lead to a weakened immune system, making the body more susceptible to infections. Lymphadenopathy (swollen lymph nodes) is a common symptom, and vision problems can occur in later stages. Anxiety may also be present due to the condition itself or its social implications.

diagnoses.name: Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Commonly caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, mononucleosis can lead to symptoms such as swollen lymph nodes, increased susceptibility to infections due to immune system engagement, and possible neurological symptoms like difficulty focusing. Coryza and anxiety can also occur.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes
diagnoses.description: Diabetes, especially when poorly controlled, can lead to increased susceptibility to infection. Vision problems are common due to the impact on blood vessels in the eyes. Anxiety can be associated with managing chronic illness.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: Systemic lupus erythematosus might cause lymphadenopathy, vulnerability to infections, and neurological symptoms that can affect vision. Anxiety is common due to living with a chronic illness.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: This autoimmune disorder can cause lymphadenopathy and increased risk of infections due to immune system dysfunction and potentially due to immunosuppressive medications. Eye problems and anxiety may also be present as part of the systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: This autoimmune disease often presents with dry eyes, which can lead to difficulty focusing vision. Lymphadenopathy and increased susceptibility to infections can occur, and the physical symptoms may contribute to anxiety.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: TB primarily affects the lungs but can also cause lymphadenopathy and systemic symptoms such as susceptibility to infection. Psychological symptoms, including anxiety, may occur due to the illness's chronic nature.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: Sarcoidosis can lead to lymphadenopathy and eye problems, including visual impairment. It can also affect the immune system, making infections more common. Anxiety may be present due to uncertainty about the disease’s course.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Lymphoma, a type of cancer that begins in the lymphatic system, often presents with lymphadenopathy. It can also weaken the immune system, leading to increased susceptibility to infections. Neurological and ocular symptoms may occur, as well as psychological impacts like anxiety.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: CFS/ME can include symptoms like swollen lymph nodes, general susceptibility to infections, visual disturbances, and coryza. Anxiety can be a significant issue, often related to the chronic management of the condition.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Inflammatory bowel disease (as a less common cause for some symptoms)
Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) - if wheezing is chronic

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic, typically progressive disease involving damage to the sheaths of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, symptoms may include numbness, impairment of speech and of muscular coordination, blurred vision and severe fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves visual disturbances and other aura symptoms. Scotoma or vision losses, headache, numbness, and weakness are common.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms can include headache, paralysis or numbness of the face, arm or leg, and difficulty speaking or understanding speech.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief, temporary disruption of blood supply to part of the brain, spinal cord, or retina, causing stroke-like symptoms such as numbness or weakness, especially on one side of the body, headache, and difficulty speaking or understanding speech.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disease that causes high blood sugar. Chronic diabetes conditions include type 1 diabetes and type 2 diabetes. Peripheral neuropathy, a result of damage to the nerves located outside of the brain and spinal cord (peripheral nerves), often causes weakness, numbness and pain, usually in your hands and feet.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Symptoms can include headaches, seizures, weakness, numbness, cognitive or speech difficulties, and vision changes, including scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition due to insufficient levels of vitamin B12, important for nerve function, red blood cell production, and DNA synthesis. Symptoms can include weakness, numbness, difficulty walking, and memory loss.

diagnoses.name: Hypertension
diagnoses.description: High blood pressure can lead to damaging of the brain's blood vessels, causing conditions such as stroke that manifest as headache, numbness, or weakness.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. Symptoms can include headache, fatigue, fever, and in severe cases, it can lead to neurological disorders like facial palsy, numbness, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues. It can cause fatigue, weakness, and headaches among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms including severe headaches, photophobia (sensitivity to light), phonophobia (sensitivity to sound), and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular neuritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the vestibular nerve that can cause vertigo, nausea, and balance problems, possibly contributing to ataxia and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system) that can cause weakness, ataxia (coordination problems), and in some cases, photophobia.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain which can cause symptoms depending on its location, such as ataxia, weakness, nausea, and sometimes, photophobia.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted, leading to brain tissue damage. Symptoms can include weakness, ataxia, and depending on the area of the brain affected, photophobia and phonophobia.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain often caused by a viral infection, presenting symptoms such as weakness, ataxia, photophobia, and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord, which can cause severe headaches, nausea, photophobia, and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: An acute condition involving bleeding into the space between the brain and the tissue covering it, causing intense headache, nausea, photophobia, and possibly ataxia if affecting certain brain areas.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: A noncancerous tumor on the main nerve leading from the inner ear to the brain. Large tumors can cause ataxia, and while photophobia and phonophobia are less common, they can appear as secondary symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Miller Fisher Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, acquired nerve disease that is considered to be a variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome. It is characterized by abnormal muscle coordination (ataxia), weakness, and in some cases, photophobia due to ophthalmoplegia.

diagnoses: Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Thrombocytopenia)
Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjögren's Syndrome
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia combined with Immune Thrombocytopenia)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
